title: How to Remove Bleach Effect from Your Face

steps.title: Use cold water or ice cubes on your face to numb the pain.
steps.content: Use cold water or ice cubes on your face to numb the pain. Splash your face gently with cold water to help relieve the burning feeling left from the bleach. You can also take an ice cube and move it over your face as it melts to help numb the skin and relieve pain from the burn. Run the ice cube under running water first so that it doesn’t stick to your skin.

steps.title: Smooth aloe vera gel on your skin to help the burn.
steps.content: Smooth aloe vera gel on your skin to help the burn. Squeeze out a dollop of aloe vera and use clean fingers to smooth it over the parts of your face that feel irritated. Use a small amount at first, adding more later on if your skin continues to burn slightly. Purchase aloe vera in a lotion or gel form from a drug store or big box store. You can also cut off a piece of an aloe vera plant, smearing the plant’s natural gel onto your face.

steps.title: Wash your face with coconut milk to soothe the skin.
steps.content: Wash your face with coconut milk to soothe the skin. Coconut milk is great for moisturizing the skin, and it has several other health benefits. Purchase coconut milk and splash it onto your face gently, You could also try soaking up coconut milk with a paper towel or cotton ball before patting your face with the liquid. Coconut milk has anti-inflammatory, antibacterial, and anti-fungal properties.

steps.title: Cover your face with potato peels for their anti-inflammatory effects.
steps.content: Cover your face with potato peels for their anti-inflammatory effects. Wash 1-2 white or yellow potatoes and then use a potato peeler to remove the outer skin from each one. Place the peels on your face twice a day for a few minutes to help soothe your skin. You may need to lay down while doing this so that the peels stay in place on your face.

steps.title: Put lavender essential oil on your face for its antiseptic qualities.
steps.content: Put lavender essential oil on your face for its antiseptic qualities. Use a cotton ball to apply the lavender essential oil to your face, making sure to dilute it first with witch hazel, coconut oil, or water. Swipe the cotton ball across the bleached area of your skin, doing this every few hours until you start to feel the effects. Purchase lavender essential oil from a big box store or online. Because it's so concentrated, dilute the lavender essential oil by combining a few drops of the lavender oil with roughly 1 teaspoon (4.9 ml) of coconut oil, witch hazel, or water.

steps.title: Avoid direct sunlight to prevent further damage.
steps.content: Avoid direct sunlight to prevent further damage. Staying out in the sun will irritate your face, causing the burning feeling to intensify. Try to avoid going outside when the sun is super bright so that your skin can heal. If you do go outside, wear a hat that helps shield your face or use an umbrella to keep your skin out of the sun.

steps.title: Stop using bleaching products immediately.
steps.content: Stop using bleaching products immediately. Get rid of your bleaching creams and skin lightening peels. This is important not only so that your skin doesn’t get any lighter, but so that you don’t cause additional damage and burning sensations. Avoid continuing with your bleaching treatment so your skin can begin to heal. [1] X Research source Be especially wary of products such as hydroquinone, as they can cause irreversible discoloration and skin darkening. [2] X Expert Source Margareth Pierre-Louis, MD Board Certified Dermatologist Expert Interview. 15 May 2020.

steps.title: See a dermatologist if you’re concerned about your skin.
steps.content: See a dermatologist if you’re concerned about your skin. If your skin is still in pain from the bleaching and isn’t getting any better, schedule an appointment with your dermatologist. They will be able to give you advice for how to soothe your skin, or may be able to prescribe you something that will help as well. [3] X Research source Call the dermatologist’s office to schedule an appointment with them.

steps.title: Use gentle cleansers to wash your face.
steps.content: Use gentle cleansers to wash your face. While your face is irritated, it’s best not to use anything too strong on it to prevent bothering it more. Use gentle, soothing soaps and cleansers if you’re going to wash your face, rinsing with cool water once you’re finished. [4] X Research source Look for cleansers that have natural ingredients in them like sea algae, turmeric, cucumber, or coconut oil. If you need to moisturize your face, use natural remedies like cucumber and honey if possible.

steps.title: Put sunscreen on your face if you’re going out in the sun.
steps.content: Put sunscreen on your face if you’re going out in the sun. It’s best to try to stay out of the sun as much as possible while your face heals, but if you have to go out in it, apply sunscreen to your face beforehand. [5] X Expert Source Margareth Pierre-Louis, MD Board Certified Dermatologist Expert Interview. 15 May 2020. Rub it in gently, paying close attention to the spots that are irritated. [6] X Research source Look for sunscreens that have both UV-A and UV-B protection. Use an SPF of 30 or higher, and reapply the sunscreen every 2 hours if you're outdoors. [7] X Expert Source Margareth Pierre-Louis, MD Board Certified Dermatologist Expert Interview. 15 May 2020.

steps.title: Eat foods that are high in carotenoids.
steps.content: Eat foods that are high in carotenoids. Carotenoids are known to give your skin a naturally darker color and have several health benefits. Incorporate foods like carrots, tomatoes, mangoes, and leafy greens into your diet to bring your skin back to its natural hue. [8] X Research source Carotenoids are pigments in plants that give off a red, orange, and yellow tint. Consuming carotenoids can help boost your immune system and prevent certain types of diseases.

steps.title: Drink lots of water.
steps.content: Drink lots of water. While you can stay hydrated by drinking other healthy options like tea or juice, water is the best option as it helps your skin heal faster. Try to drink at least 8 c (1.9 l) of water a day, drinking even more if possible. [9] X Trustworthy Source University of Wisconsin Health Integrated healthcare system of the University of Wisconsin focused on treating and providing support to patients and public health initiatives Go to source It's recommended that the average person drink 8 c (1.9 l) of water, while small children may need to drink less.

steps.title: Give your face time to heal.
steps.content: Give your face time to heal. While you may want a more immediate fix, time is ultimately the thing that will help your skin get back to normal. Continue being gentle with your skin and give it a couple weeks to heal. If your skin isn’t feeling better within a week or two, it might be time to schedule an appointment with a doctor.
